In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        throw(ErrorException("Input should be a DateTime type"))
    end
    
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```
This function `timezone_bumper` first checks if the provided input is of DateTime type or not, if it is not then it throws an error message. If the input is a valid DateTime object then it adds bump hours to that time and returns the resultant date-time.
